column4: you can just redirect any output using sort -u file.txt > file2.txt or use the -o option
.. try also reading the ouput of 'man sort'
why do i keep getting back No such file or directory...i'm in the directory the file is in...???
.. what command are you using exactly?
Desktop$ sort -u fu.txt>fu2.txt
whats the output of 'which sort'
you mean output from ls?
no just type 'which sort' for me please (with out the quotes) on your computer
/usr/bin/sort
was that what you're after?
/usr/bin/sort: open failed: fu.txt: No such file or directory
then the file you are trying to sort is not named fu.txt or isnt it the current directory
ok it's a gedit file called fu...i assumed it would have a .txt extension
no linux is never aware of extension really..
great then Desktop$ sort -u fu>fu2 worked like a charm. Thanks
yw
yw?
yw == your welcome
ah cool ...cheers
sorry mate..the list size has been reduced. what it did was put it into alphabetical order and reduce the size but there are still quite a few repeats in there. any ideas?
the -u option sorts and keeps uniques only if thats what you want?
the -n option sorts on numbers .. etc etc. See 'man sort'
that's what i thought but sort -u fu>fu2 didn't remove all duplicates...I'll look cheers
i cant judge until i see what the file is made of :) sorry
